sentences: Yasushi Akutagawa (芥川 也寸志, Akutagawa Yasushi, July 12, 1925 – January 31, 1989) was a Japanese composer and conductor.
section: N/A

sentences: He was born and raised in Tabata, Tokyo.
section: N/A
N/A
== Biography ==
== Biography ==

sentences: Akutagawa studied composition with Kunihiko Hashimoto, Kan'ichi Shimofusa and Akira Ifukube at the Tokyo Music School.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: He was one of the members of Sannin no kai (The Three) along with Ikuma Dan and Toshiro Mayuzumi.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: In 1954, when Japan did not have diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union yet, he entered the Soviet Union illegally, and made friends with Dmitri Shostakovich, Aram Khachaturian and Dmitri Kabalevsky.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: Akutagawa was the only Japanese composer whose works were officially published in the Soviet Union at that time.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: His 1950 Music for Symphony Orchestra reflects his love of the music of Shostakovich and Prokofiev.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: His compositions were influenced by Stravinsky, Shostakovich, Prokofiev and Akira Ifukube.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: He was popular as a master of ceremonies of TV shows as well.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: As an educator, he devoted himself to train an amateur orchestra, Shin Kokyo Gakudan ("The New Symphony Orchestra").
section: == Biography ==

sentences: Almost one year after Akutagawa died, in 1990, the Akutagawa composition award was established in his memory.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: Akutagawa and The New Symphony Orchestra are the recipient of the 1976 Suntory Music Award.
section: == Biography ==
